document.docTitle: Grazing activity of Clibanarius corallinus (H. Milne Edwards, 1848) (Decapoda: Anomura: Diogenidae) on epilithic algae in Australian coral reefs

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Grazing activity of Clibanarius corallinus (H. Milne Edwards, 1848) (Decapoda: Anomura: Diogenidae) on epilithic algae in Australian coral reefs

mods:name.mods:affiliation: School of Biological Sciences, The University of Queensland, St Lucia, Brisbane, Queensland 4072, Australia & Groningen Institute for Evolutionary Life Sciences (GELIFES), University of Groningen, 9700 CC Groningen, The Netherlands
School of Biological Sciences, The University of Queensland, St Lucia, Brisbane, Queensland 4072, Australia

paragraph.docTitle:
Grazing activity of
Clibanarius corallinus (H. Milne Edwards, 1848 )
( Decapoda : Anomura: Diogenidae ) on epilithic algae in Australian coral reefs

subSection.paragraph: Henrique Bravo 1,2, and Ian R. Tibbetts 1

materialsCitation.docAuthorAffiliation: School of Biological Sciences , The University of Queensland , St Lucia, Brisbane, Queensland 4072, Australia

paragraph.docAuthorAffiliation:
Groningen Institute for Evolutionary Life Sciences (GELIFES), University of Groningen , 9700 CC
Groningen , The Netherlands

subSection.paragraph: Correspondence:H.Bravo; e-mail: henrique.bravo@rug.nl

heading.emphasis: A B ST R A CT

subSection.paragraph:
Following an incidental observation of captive
Clibanarius corallinus (H. Milne Edwards, 1848 )
supposedly removing algae from each other’s shells, we conducted a feeding experiment over 72 hours to understand its potential role as a mesograzer in coral reef ecosystems. Epiphytecovered, coral rubble fragments of
Acropora spp.
were exposed to hermit crab ( N = 41) activity for 72 h in a flow-through seawater aquarium system at Heron Island, southern Great Barrier Reef, Australia to understand whether hermit crabs could remove epilithic algae and if so, to what extent. Coral fragments exposed to the hermit crabs had 9.1% less chlorophyll at the end of the experiment. The detritus generated in the experimental set-up had 2.4 times more chlorophyll and 33.4% less organic biomass than the detritus generated in the control environment. The crabs did on average lose 0.11 g of their initial weight, which could have been a consequence of the experimental set-up. These results suggest that
C. corallinus
has the potential to contribute to the control of epilithic algae in coral reefs, with such effect having hitherto been overlooked as a result of the cryptic behaviour of this hermit crab species.

paragraph.heading: KEY WORDS: Crustacea , Great Barrier Reef , Heron Island , mesograzer , reef flat

subSection.paragraph:
In an unpublished study (IRT, unpublished data), individuals of the hermit crab
Clibanarius corallinus (H. Milne Edwards, 1848 )
captured from Heron Island’s reef flat were kept in a bare saltwater aquarium overnight. The following morning, their shell homes, which when placed in the aquarium had been covered with a coat of epilithic algae, were bare. Presumably the hermit crabs had removed the algae from each other’s shells during this period. This observation led us to hypothesise that these hermit crabs might contribute to reef grazing by feeding on epilithic algae.

Here we report the results of a short-term aquarium-based experiment to determine whether
C. corallinus
is a potential member of the reef mesograzer assemblage, because whilst there is evidence of a preference for epilithic algae in congeners in other environments ( Kunze & Anderson, 1979 ;
Benvenuto et al ., 2003
; Tran, 2014 ), nothing has been reported for this particular species of hermit crab as of yet. Specifically, we estimated chlorophyll removed by the crabs, as a proxy for algal grazing. We hypothesised that treatments with hermit crabs would have less chlorophyll on the coral substrate and that hermit crabs would remove more organic biomass in the dislodged detritus than controls that lacked their presence.

paragraph.heading: M AT E R I A L S A N D M ET H O D S

subSection.paragraph:
Forty-one individuals of
C. corallinus
were collected from the near-shore reef flat in August 2014 on the southern shore of Heron Island (
23°26 ʹ 35.5″S
,
151°54 ʹ 46.3″E
) where they are known to congregate in high numbers at low tide ( Tudge, 1995 ). The reef flat, where they are commonly found, is dominated by coarse carbonate sand and coral fragments with few live corals and is less than 50 cm in depth at low tide. In addition, 82 dead and epilithic algal-covered
Acropora spp.
coral rubble fragments were collected from the same area in which the hermit crabs had been collected, since this is on what they were previously seen feeding during in vivo observations.

Crabs were placed in 41 individual 50 ml perforated plastic containers inside an aquarium that was located outdoors, in a shaded area, and that was constantly supplied with flow-through sea water drawn in from the reef flat to mimic natural conditions (Supplementary material Figs. S1 , S2). Food was withheld for 24 h prior to the start of the experiment to eliminate any previously consumed material and avoid any overestimation in chlorophyll in faeces from feeding activity prior to collection. The experimental period started when we placed a piece of dead coral fragment ( 4–5 cm ) with its associated epilithic algae inside the plastic container. A plastic mesh was placed several centimetres above the bottom of the container to prevent the crabs from eating either the material dislodged from the coral or their own faeces.
Chlorophyll concentration in milligrams per square centimetre was calculated using an equation initially proposed by Jeffrey & Humphrey (1975) :
solution volume (11.85 × OD 664 − 1.54× Chla mg × cm−2 = OD647 − 0.08 × OD630) mg l− l
scraped surface area
where OD is optical density.

The detritus was placed in separate pre-weighed crucibles and weighed again before and after treatment in a muffle furnace (S.E.M, Ferntree Gully, Australia ) at 450 ºC for 4 h. Organic biomass that was originally present in the detritus was estimated by subtracting the final ash weight from the original detritus weight, obtaining an ash-free dry weight.

The 41 individuals of
C. corallinus
occupied shells that had an average length of 26 mm (± 4.7 mm ) and were observed feeding both day and night using their chelipeds to remove material from the coral fragments. They were also observed feeding, in some instances, on dislodged detritus trapped in the plastic mesh near the base of the container.

After 72 h, coral fragments that were exposed to individuals of
C. corallinus
had significantly less chlorophyll than those in a control environment (Χ 2 = 0.073, df = 1, P = 0.003; Fig. 1A ). Chlorophyll was, on average, 9.1% lower in the coral fragments grazed by hermit crabs.

At the end of the experiment, there was more detritus generated, on average, in each of the containers with crabs (5.91 ± 3.21), compared to those in the control containers (5.07 ± 2.33). Mean chlorophyll in the detritus generated by the hermit crabs, faeces included, was more than double that in the control treatment (Χ 2 = 0.052, df = 1, P <0.001; Fig. 1B ). Chlorophyll was approximately 2.4 times higher in the detritus in the grazed treatment, having a mean of 0.05 mg g –1 (± 0.01) compared to a mean of 0.02 mg g –1 (± 0.01) in the control treatment.

Hermit crabs were also responsible for a significant reduction of organic biomass in the detritus when compared to organic biomass in detritus in the control treatment (Χ 2 = 0.088, df = 1, P = 0.003). The amount of organic biomass was 33.4% lower in the grazed treatment ( 0.132 ± 0.407 g ) compared to the control treatment (0.198 ± 0.133 g ; Fig. 1C ).

The weight of the crabs before (4.55 ± 2.80 g ) and after (4.44 ± 2.70 g ) the treatmen, differed significantly (V = 755.5, df = 40, P < 0.001), which indicates that they lost on average 2.4% ( 0.11 g ) of their initial weight over the course of the experiment (Supplementary material Fig. S3).

Our data confirm that
C. corallinus
can graze epilithic algae, and thereby potentially contribute to reef health. Such finding

caption.paragraph:
Figure 1. Boxplots showing: chlorophyll present in samples taken from the surface of
Acropora spp.
coral rubble fragments for the control (without hermit crabs) and grazed treatment (with
Clibanarius corallinus
hermit crabs), expressed in mg cm –2 ( A ); differences in chlorophyll in detritus that was displaced from the coral fragment (adjusted for the total amount of detritus) ( B ) and; the amount of organic biomass displaced from the coral fragments between different treatments (adjusted for the amount of detritus) ( C ).

subSection.paragraph:
The individuals of
C. corallinus
we used were subject to food deprivation for a period of 24 h, an amount of time that can significantly decrease the weight of hermit crabs ( Laidre & Elwood, 2008 ) and which can alter feeding preference ( Cronin & Hay, 1996 ). Hermit crabs in our experiment experienced a minor but statistically significant weight loss after 72 h (Supplementary material Fig. S3). Given that the weight loss was minimal and considering the coral rubble habitat in which these crabs were found, we suggest that epilithic algae are an important food source for the hermit crabs. The small weight loss could either be due to the absence of other food sources or to the 24-h food deprivation period. Food choice experiments would be required to identify other foods in the trophic repertoire of
C. corallinus
.

In this short-term feeding experiment, we showed that
C. corallinus
can remove epilithic algae growing on dead coral fragments. These hermit crabs, for their part, can aid the reefs in regulating the growth of algae due to the crabs’ active grazing, potentially making this relationship a mutually beneficial one. Given the possibility of hermit crabs to access small spaces that other grazers cannot and their increased grazing activity when present in more exposed areas (
Altman-Kurosaki et al ., 2018
), it is expected that the role of this and other meso- and micrograzers (e.g., other species of crustaceans, molluscs, and other small invertebrates) has been overlooked when predicting food web dynamics in reef systems. Our study is therefore one of the few investigations that looks at the ecology of a particular grazing species providing information that can be useful for future studies, particularly in the field of whole-ecosystem studies or in predicting future ecosystem changes by looking at the functional traits of species that inhabit a specific habitat.
Supplementary material is available at Journal of Crustacean Biology online.

S1 Figure. Aquarium showing individuals of
Clibanarius corallinus
and fragments of
Acropora spp.
S2 Figure. Plan view of the experimental set-up.

S3 Figure. Boxplot with average weight of the 41 hermit crabs before (left) and after (right) the experiment. Individual crabs are depicted with points and the grey lines link their initial and final weights.

paragraph.heading: ACK N O W LE D G E M E N TS

subSection.paragraph: We thank Dr Carolina Castro-Sanguino for her time, equipment and willingness to make this experiment possible, Catriona Glendinning for assistance with collection of hermit crabs, and the staff of Heron Island Research Station, particularly Science Officer Kathy La Fauce. We further thank the helpful and useful feedback from two anonymous reviewers and the Associate Editor, Dr Edwin Cruz-Rivera, which significantly improved the manuscript. The authors have no competing interests to declare that are relevant to the content of this article.
